awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A History of Oil Infrastructures: Commodity Production and Consumption
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a doctoral dissertation research project on the history of infrastructures of oil, meaning the designate socio-technical assemblages designed to transport oil, to enable the exchange of other commodities via petroleum-powered transportation technologies, and to absorb and direct flows of capital derived from oil. The project asks three core questions: How do oil infrastructures produce and shape national space? How do infrastructures redistribute agency and imbue political projects with momentum? And how do infrastructures serve as contested sites of capital accumulation? Building on recent contributions to Science and Technology Studies, this project attempts to answer these questions using a diverse array of archival resources to examine six oil infrastructure projects. The researcher plans to publish the results of this project as peer-reviewed articles, and he will use his dissertation as the initial draft of a book monograph for academics, policymakers, and members of the general public. He also plans to use these results to reach out to policy audiences at conferences and in peer-reviewed policy venues.

This research on oil infrastructures promises to make novel contributions to three distinct subfields of Science and Technology Studies: History of Technology, Environmental History, and Infrastructure Studies. It shifts from a conventional focus on commodity production and consumption within environmental history and studies of extractive industries toward an analysis of the flows of energy, commodities, and capital that tie together the oil industry. It intentionally brings material and capital flows into the same analytical frame in order to provide a more complete account of the socio-technical networks that historically constituted the oil industry, and to better understand the materiality of struggles over the distribution of oil wealth. As decarbonization advances worldwide, spaces built around infrastructures designed to transport and refine oil, facilitate petroleum-powered trade, and absorb or direct flows of oil wealth will need to confront the momentum and path dependency that such infrastructures have produced, as well as looming prospects of infrastructural abandonment and capital flight. This research will aid citizens and policymakers in making historically informed decisions about energy policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examines the ways in which infrastructure projects connected to the international oil industry shaped the politics, economy, and built environment of Lebanon between the 1920s and the 1970s. It is based upon archival documents held at archives located in Lebanon, the United Kingdom, and the United States, including the Lebanese National Archive, the American University of Beirut, the National Archives of the United Kingdom, the British Library, and the New York State Archives.

First and foremost, this project advances scholarship in Science and Technology Studies and the political economy of oil. It is analytically concerned with how specific infrastructures aided in the assembly of Lebanon as a space of energy, commodity, and capital flows. It asks how these infrastructures persistently conditioned the distribution of political agency and economic resources within and through the national space of Lebanon. By analyzing material and capital flows together, this framing allows an examination of the concrete materiality of struggles over oil wealth and permits an analysis of the formation of the Lebanese state and economy as the outcome of both technological momentum and political-economic path dependency. Whereas a large literature on the political economy of oil in the Arab Gulf states already exists, this project also aims to render visible the centrality of Lebanon to the network of sociotechnical assemblages that historically constituted the global oil industry and the capital flows it generated. Finally, it seeks to integrate STS approaches to infrastructure projects as means of stabilizing long-term capital accumulation with an emergent scholarship on the role of transnational Gulf capital in the regional political economy of the Middle East.

It also advances scholarship on environmental history and the national history of Lebanon.  Environmental historians have shown how national economic and state spaces are produced through transnational patterns of natural resource extraction, commodity production, and exchange. They have also analyzed how these dynamics of extraction, production, and exchange transform the built environment, and how social groups shaped history through their control over infrastructures and labor processes. I build on this work by asking how infrastructures designed to channel energy, commodities, and capital through Lebanon altered the built environment and thus reshaped the material and institutional terrain over and through which contests over power and resources unfolded. This project also builds on recent work that aims to counter a scholarly tendency to treat Lebanon as a historical exception, noteworthy for its sectarian fragmentation and its failure to produce a strong state or popular movements capable of achieving redistributive gains. To that end, it foregrounds a history of popular contestation revolving around the infrastructure projects on which it focuses, and on the role played by infrastructures in producing a particular kind of state space in Lebanon, culminating in the creation of an incipient welfare state by the 1970s.

This project will also contribute to public and policy discourse as Lebanon explores for hydrocarbon resources amidst overlapping political, economic, fiscal, and infrastructural crises in the wake of Lebanon’s October 2019 uprising, the global Covid-19 pandemic, the August 2020 Beirut port explosion, and Lebanon’s ongoing fiscal crisis. For elites, offshore hydrocarbons seem to offer an opportunity to resolve Lebanon’s multiple crises while avoiding concessions to popular forces by allowing the Lebanese state to secure revenue without changing its regressive tax structure and to expand electricity provision while avoiding the shift toward renewables. This project warns against elite fantasies that fossil fuel resources can neatly resolve Lebanon’s crises.

Finally, although this project focuses on Lebanon, its insights are not limited to the history of this small country. As the world makes its gradual transition away from fossil fuels, we all must live in the ruins of the old fossil energy regime even as new renewable energy systems emerge from it. Our societies exist suspended between infrastructures like highways, power plants, and petrochemical complexes that lock us into fossil fuel consumption. At the same time, we confront the very real consequences of infrastructure abandonment in fracking fields, offshore oil rigs, and coal mines, as well as the immediate and long-term ruination of climate change and environmental sacrifice zones. Meanwhile capital – especially finance capital – flits between investment and abandonment, forming path dependencies and leaving ruin, stabilizing its own accumulation while destabilizing social and ecological relations.
